pr_title: XRDDEV-882/883 APIs for adding and deleting configured timestamping services

timeline.message:
XRDDEV-910 API for listing configured timestamping services

- Implement API for listing configured timestamping services.
- Update OpenAPI description.
- Add unit tests.
- Enable eager loading of configured timestamping services in serverconf DAO.
- Implement reverse ordering of returned timestamping services so that they're in the order used by proxy.

XRDDEV-910 Fix proxy-ui-api incorrect target folder in Ansible script

- Change proxy-ui-api target folder from /usr/share/xroad/jlib/webapps to /usr/share/xroad/jlib.

XRDDEV-910 Update unit tests

- Add new test that verifies that timestamping services are returned in reverse order.

XRDDEV-910 Refactor loading of configured timestamping services

- Revert changes in server conf DAO.
- Use Hibernate.initialize to load timestamping service objects.
- Remove reverse ordering of returned timestamping services.

XRDDEV-883 API for deleting configured timestamping services

- Implement API for deleting configured timestamping services.
- Update OpenAPI description.
- Add unit tests.
XRDDEV-910 Refactor API and service layers
XRDDEV-883 Merge changes from branch XRDDEV-910

XRDDEV-882 API for adding new configured timestamping services

- Implement API for adding new configured timestamping services.
- Add unit tests.

timeline.body:
Instead of multi-type-converters with instanceof conditional it would probably be more consistent with the existing converters to have separate `convert(Iterable<String> list)` and `convert(<TspType> list)` methods. 

I have another suggestion about removing convert(Iterable<String>) altogether elsewhere, though.
timeline.bodyText:
Instead of multi-type-converters with instanceof conditional it would probably be more consistent with the existing converters to have separate convert(Iterable<String> list) and convert(<TspType> list) methods.
I have another suggestion about removing convert(Iterable) altogether elsewhere, though.
timeline.bodyHTML:
Instead of multi-type-converters with instanceof conditional it would probably be more consistent with the existing converters to have separate convert(Iterable<String> list) and convert(<TspType> list) methods.

I have another suggestion about removing convert(Iterable) altogether elsewhere, though.
timeline.author: jansu76

replies.bodyText:
Having methods convert(Iterable<String> list) and convert(Iterable<TspType> list) is not possible, because they still have the same erasure.
One alternative would be name them differently, e.g., convertString(Iterable<String> list) and convertTspType(Iterable<TspType> list).
replies.author: petkivim

replies.bodyText: Ah, I did not realize that. Yeah, different names could be one option. I am still thinking we could avoid that though - more at #372 (comment).
replies.author: jansu76

timeline.body: What do you think about changing this to public `Collection<TspType> getApprovedTimestampingServices()` with TspType.id = null (and documenting that in the javadoc)? That would make it easier for the callers to handle both types of timestamping services with same constructs, especially it would enable bit of simplification for TimestampingServiceConverter and remove globalConfFacade calls from it. It would make converter layer more thin and dumb and I think unless there's some trouble related to that, we should try to do that to focus business logic inside the service layer. There's some exceptions to this (member name lookups, security server owner lookups) but ideally they should be minimized.
timeline.bodyText: What do you think about changing this to public Collection<TspType> getApprovedTimestampingServices() with TspType.id = null (and documenting that in the javadoc)? That would make it easier for the callers to handle both types of timestamping services with same constructs, especially it would enable bit of simplification for TimestampingServiceConverter and remove globalConfFacade calls from it. It would make converter layer more thin and dumb and I think unless there's some trouble related to that, we should try to do that to focus business logic inside the service layer. There's some exceptions to this (member name lookups, security server owner lookups) but ideally they should be minimized.
timeline.bodyHTML: What do you think about changing this to public Collection<TspType> getApprovedTimestampingServices() with TspType.id = null (and documenting that in the javadoc)? That would make it easier for the callers to handle both types of timestamping services with same constructs, especially it would enable bit of simplification for TimestampingServiceConverter and remove globalConfFacade calls from it. It would make converter layer more thin and dumb and I think unless there's some trouble related to that, we should try to do that to focus business logic inside the service layer. There's some exceptions to this (member name lookups, security server owner lookups) but ideally they should be minimized.
timeline.author: jansu76

replies.bodyText: I ended up removing the whole TimestampingServiceService class since it was not really needed after the API changes.
replies.author: petkivim

replies.bodyText:
All right. The question about converter / service roles remains still though.
What do you think about something like this: e750d03 ?
I think TimestampingServiceConverter and GlobalConfService are a bit more close to what their roles "usually" are, and converter is thinner and dumber.
Disclaimer: I did not live test this. Automatic tests pass though.
replies.author: jansu76

replies.bodyText:
I think that your solution looks good. Now the service layer returns TspType objects for both approved and configured  timestamping services which makes the implementation more consistent and simplifies the converter.
I merged the changes, tested the API manually, and everything works as expected.
replies.author: petkivim

timeline.body: There is a possibility to simplify a little bit these "find first match" checks by using streams, as in e.g. https://github.com/nordic-institute/X-Road/blob/c5d76583de6f3a9e8d91cb13c41f1e1b7c64c54f/src/proxy-ui-api/src/main/java/org/niis/xroad/restapi/service/ClientService.java#L237-L242
timeline.bodyHTML:
There is a possibility to simplify a little bit these "find first match" checks by using streams, as in e.g.

X-Road/src/proxy-ui-api/src/main/java/org/niis/xroad/restapi/service/ClientService.java

Lines 237 to 242 in c5d7658

Optional<CertificateType> duplicate = clientType.getIsCert().stream()
.filter(cert -> hash.equalsIgnoreCase(calculateCertHexHash(cert.getData())))
.findFirst();
if (duplicate.isPresent()) {
throw new CertificateAlreadyExistsException("certificate already exists");
}
timeline.author: jansu76

timeline.body:
We've used a convention where ResourceNotFoundException is reserved for resource as in http URL. So since resource is `/timestamping-services`, that resource exists and the problem is in the request body, not the "resource" identified by the URL. By that logic this would be a BadRequestException (a problem with request body).

An example of this https://github.com/nordic-institute/X-Road/blob/c5d76583de6f3a9e8d91cb13c41f1e1b7c64c54f/src/proxy-ui-api/src/main/java/org/niis/xroad/restapi/openapi/TokensApiController.java#L207-L222 where ClientNotFoundException -> BadRequestException and TokenNotFoundException -> ResourceNotFound (token id is in the URL)
timeline.bodyHTML:
We've used a convention where ResourceNotFoundException is reserved for resource as in http URL. So since resource is /timestamping-services, that resource exists and the problem is in the request body, not the "resource" identified by the URL. By that logic this would be a BadRequestException (a problem with request body).

An example of this

X-Road/src/proxy-ui-api/src/main/java/org/niis/xroad/restapi/openapi/TokensApiController.java

Lines 207 to 222 in c5d7658

try {
keyAndCertRequest = keyAndCertificateRequestService.addKeyAndCertRequest(
tokenId, keyLabelWithCsrGenerate.getKeyLabel(),
memberId,
keyUsageInfo,
csrGenerate.getCaName(),
csrGenerate.getSubjectFieldValues(),
csrFormat);
} catch (ClientNotFoundException | CertificateAuthorityNotFoundException
| DnFieldHelper.InvalidDnParameterException e) {
throw new BadRequestException(e);
} catch (ActionNotPossibleException e) {
throw new ConflictException(e);
} catch (TokenNotFoundException e) {
throw new ResourceNotFoundException(e);
}
where ClientNotFoundException -> BadRequestException and TokenNotFoundException -> ResourceNotFound (token id is in the URL)
timeline.author: jansu76
jansu76

timeline.body:
We have used convention where response has Location header which points to created entity. There is a helper to make this convenient, https://github.com/nordic-institute/X-Road/blob/c5d76583de6f3a9e8d91cb13c41f1e1b7c64c54f/src/proxy-ui-api/src/main/java/org/niis/xroad/restapi/openapi/ClientsApiController.java#L308

We do not have a single-item-getter for timestamping services, so I wonder which would be better, a) point to all-items-getter `/token-certificates` or b) not include Location header at all?
timeline.bodyText:

      in
      c5d7658
    
    
    
    

        
          
           return createCreatedResponse("/api/local-groups/{id}", createdGroup, localGroupType.getId()); 
        
    
  


We do not have a single-item-getter for timestamping services, so I wonder which would be better, a) point to all-items-getter /token-certificates or b) not include Location header at all?
timeline.bodyHTML:
We have used convention where response has Location header which points to created entity. There is a helper to make this convenient,

X-Road/src/proxy-ui-api/src/main/java/org/niis/xroad/restapi/openapi/ClientsApiController.java

Line 308 in c5d7658

return createCreatedResponse("/api/local-groups/{id}", createdGroup, localGroupType.getId());

We do not have a single-item-getter for timestamping services, so I wonder which would be better, a) point to all-items-getter /token-certificates or b) not include Location header at all?
timeline.author: jansu76

replies.bodyText: I ended up leaving this as-is - not including Location header since we do not have an endpoint for a single timestamping entity.
replies.author: petkivim

replies.bodyText: With a fresh mind this (b) is indeed the better option since it is better to not provide wrong Location header if we cannot provide a correct one.  Discussed same thing with @TJaakkola today, about Endpoint delete, since we don't have a single item getter for that either.
replies.author: jansu76

timeline.body:
Consider making timestampingServiceService.addConfiguredTimestampingService `public TimestampingService addConfiguredTimestampingService(TimestampingService timestampingServiceToAdd)` and returning the created object? 

Now if I understand correctly API returns partial TimestampingService object with empty updated_at, message and status? This is a bit inconsistent with how other creates work, an example:

https://github.com/nordic-institute/X-Road/blob/c5d76583de6f3a9e8d91cb13c41f1e1b7c64c54f/src/proxy-ui-api/src/main/java/org/niis/xroad/restapi/openapi/ClientsApiController.java#L299-L307

It probably does not make sense to go through lots of effort to get this perfect, but at least low hanging fruits can be picked.

Something in guidelines about this: https://confluence.niis.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=8520435#APIGuidelines&Examples-POSTandPUTshouldreturnusefuldatapostputconvention
timeline.bodyHTML:
Consider making timestampingServiceService.addConfiguredTimestampingService public TimestampingService addConfiguredTimestampingService(TimestampingService timestampingServiceToAdd) and returning the created object?

Now if I understand correctly API returns partial TimestampingService object with empty updated_at, message and status? This is a bit inconsistent with how other creates work, an example:

X-Road/src/proxy-ui-api/src/main/java/org/niis/xroad/restapi/openapi/ClientsApiController.java

Lines 299 to 307 in c5d7658

try {
localGroupType = localGroupService.addLocalGroup(clientType.getIdentifier(),
localGroupConverter.convert(localGroup));
} catch (LocalGroupService.DuplicateLocalGroupCodeException e) {
throw new ConflictException(e);
} catch (ClientNotFoundException e) {
throw new ResourceNotFoundException(e);
}
LocalGroup createdGroup = localGroupConverter.convert(localGroupType);

It probably does not make sense to go through lots of effort to get this perfect, but at least low hanging fruits can be picked.

Something in guidelines about this: https://confluence.niis.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=8520435#APIGuidelines&Examples-POSTandPUTshouldreturnusefuldatapostputconvention
timeline.author: jansu76

replies.bodyText: I removed updated_at, message and status from the TimestampingService object that os used by /system/timestamping-servicesAPI since those attributes are related to the Diagnostics only. I created a new object TimestampingServiceDiagnostics that has those attributes. After the change the API returns a full object with all the attributes (name, url) populated.
replies.author: petkivim

timeline.message:
XRDDEV-883 Updates based on review comments

- Refactor timestamping services API structure
- Move configured timestamping services endpoints under /system
- Remove updated_at, message and status attributes from TimestampingService object
- Create new TimestampingServiceDiagnostics object
- Update unit tests
XRDDEV-883 alternative converter/service allocation of responsibilities
